A drop in the price of oil below $50 a barrel, lingering uncertainty about the U.S. presidential election and growing expectations of a rate increase by the Federal Reserve, also contributed to the downbeat mood. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 53.76 points, or 0.3%, at 18,169.27, as shares of Home Depot weighed on blue-chips with a 3.2% decline. Earlier, the average had been down as many as 71 points. The Nasdaq Composite Index gave up 26.45 points, or 0.5%, to wrap at 5,283.40. The S&P 500 declined by 8.17 points, or 0.4%, to 2,143.16. Nine of the 11 main sectors ended in the red. The consumer-discretionary closed off 1.2%, while materials lost 1%. Shares of Dow component 3M fell 2.9% after reporting earnings that beat Wall Street expectations, but the company posted sales that were flat relative to the prior year and reduced the top end of its yearly earnings forecast. Market participants have been wrestling with third-quarter earnings that have outperformed lowered expectations, but a number of companies have cut their annual outlooks, which has raised questions about future earnings. Investors were eager to find out the results from two of the tech giants this week, with Apple reporting after the closing bell on Tuesday. Traders continued to eye economic data for hints on the prospects for a Federal Reserve interest-rate increase before the end of the year. Higher rates tend to send investors away from precious metals into investments that carry a yield. A reading on consumer confidence Tuesday showed a decline to 98.6 in October, a three-month low, from 103.5 in September. The FHFA Housing Price Index for August rose 0.7%, which followed an increase of 0.5% in July. Separately, the Case-Shiller 20-city Home Price Index for August rose 5.1%, which fell in-line with the consensus. This followed the previous month's unrevised reading of 5.0%. Shares in Whirlpool dropped 11% after the appliance maker reported third-quarter profit and sales that missed expectations, and issued a downbeat outlook. Merck & Co. rose 2% after the drugmaker's third-quarter earnings and sales came in above expectations. Chemicals maker DuPont& Co. shares fell 0.7% despite the company raising its yearly profit forecast and better-than-expected quarterly earnings. The company is working on its merger with Dow Chemical. Procter & Gamble gained 3.4% after the consumer goods company reported earnings ahead of forecasts. Lockheed Martin shares jumped 7.4% after the aerospace company posted higher-than-expected revenue and hiked its dividend. Baker Hughes shares rallied 4.3% after the oil-field services company reported a narrower-than-expected loss. General Motors shares ended down 4.2% even as auto giant's quarterly profit doubled. GM also posted higher revenue on strong U.S. truck sales. But it signaled continued weakness in Europe because of the fallout from the U.K.'s pending exit from the European Union, or Brexit. Crude futures fell on Tuesday, 25 October 2016 with prices in New York settling below $50 a barrel for the first time in just over a week, pressured by the possibility that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' plan to curb output will fail after Iraq signaled unwillingness to take part in the proposed deal. December West Texas Intermediate crude fell by 56 cents, or 1.1%, to settle at $49.96 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. That was the lowest settlement and first finish below $50 since 17 October 2016. OPEC members in late September reached a preliminary agreement to limit the group's daily production to between 32.5 million to 33 million barrels a day. Bullion prices ended higher at Comex on Tuesday, 25 october 2016. Gold futures settled Tuesday at their highest level in about three weeks, rebounding from the previous day's decline as uncertainty ahead of the U.S. presidential election, some weakness in the U.S. dollar and a fall in domestic equities boosted the metal's appeal. December gold rose $9.90, or 0.8%, to settle at $1,273.60 an ounce. Prices settled at their highest level since 3 October 2016. Prices are still down about 3.1% so far this month. December silver gained 17.6 cents, or 1%, to $17.78 an ounce. Treasuries finished on a mixed note with the short end of the curve underperforming. The yield on the 2-yr note rose two basis points to 0.86% while the yield on the benchmark 10-yr note ended down one basis point at 1.76%. Today's trading volume was below the average of 853 million as 819 million shares changed hands at the NYSE floor. Tomorrow's economic data will include the weekly MBA Mortgage Index and International Trade in Goods for September, which will be released at 7:00 ET and 8:30 ET, respectively. The day's data will be capped off with the 10:00 ET release of New Home Sales for September (consensus 610k). Powered by Capital Market - Live News (This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.) The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index remains just above the 1,675-point plateau, and the market is looking at another soft start on Wednesday. The global forecast for the Asian markets suggests mild consolidation thanks to weak earnings news and economic data, plus a decline in the price of crude oil. The European and U.S. markets were down and the Asian bourses figure to follow suit. The KLCI finished barely lower on Tuesday as losses from the plantation stocks and industrial issues were mitigated by support from the financial shares. For the day, the index eased 0.33 points or 0.02 percent to finish at 1,677.43 after trading between 1,673.18 and 1,677.44. Volume was 1.43 billion shares worth 1.8 billion ringgit. There were 421 decliners and 334 gainers, with 408 stocks finishing unchanged. Among the actives, MISC, Public Bank, Maxis and BAT all finished lower, while IHH Healthcare was unchanged and Sime Darby, Tenaga Nasional, Hong Leong Bank and Maybank all ended higher. The lead from Wall Street is soft as stocks moved lower on Tuesday, although the downside was fairly limited. The S&P 500 fell 8.17 points or 0.38 percent to 2,143.15, while the NASDAQ slid 26.43 points or 0.50 percent to 5,283.40 and the Dow lost 53.76 points or 0.30 percent to 18,169.27. The weakness came as traders reacted to the latest earnings news, with Sonic (SONC) reporting better than expected fiscal Q4 earnings but providing disappointing guidance. Also, Under Amour (UA) said its growth rate was slowing, while Procter & Gamble (PG) reported results that beat estimates. In economic news, the Conference Board noted a bigger than expected drop in consumer confidence in October. Falling crude oil prices also weighed as Dec. The Jakarta Composite Index now rests just beneath the 5,400-point plateau, and the market may extend its losses on Wednesday. The global forecast for the Asian markets suggests mild consolidation thanks to weak earnings news and economic data, plus a decline in the price of crude oil. The European and U.S. markets were down and the Asian bourses figure to follow suit. The JCI finished modestly lower on Tuesday following weakness from the telecoms and mixed performances from the financial shares and resource stocks. For the day, the index sank 23.18 points or 0.43 percent to finish at the daily low of 5,397.82 after peaking at 5,436.21. There were 161 decliners and 154 gainers, with 98 stocks finishing unchanged. Among the actives, Astra Agro Lestari climbed 1.79 percent, while Aneka Tambang shed 0.60 percent, Vale Indonesia added 0.37 percent, Bank Negara Indonesia collected 0.46 percent, Bank Danamon Indonesia plummeted 2.76 percent, XL Axiata skidded 2.42 percent, Indocement picked up 0.30 percent and Indofood jumped 1.05 percent. The lead from Wall Street is soft as stocks moved lower on Tuesday, although the downside was fairly limited. The S&P 500 fell 8.17 points or 0.38 percent to 2,143.15, while the NASDAQ slid 26.43 points or 0.50 percent to 5,283.40 and the Dow lost 53.76 points or 0.30 percent to 18,169.27. The weakness came as traders reacted to the latest earnings news, with Sonic (SONC) reporting better than expected fiscal Q4 earnings but providing disappointing guidance. Also, Under Amour (UA) said its growth rate was slowing, while Procter & Gamble (PG) reported results that beat estimates. In economic news, the Conference Board noted a bigger than expected drop in consumer confidence in October. Falling crude oil prices also weighed as Dec. WTI oil fell 56 cents or 1.1 percent to $49.96/bbl. by RTT Staff Writer For comments and feedback: editorial@rttnews.com Market Analysis The Most Influential Books In Business Fed Chatterbox: Economic Preview Week of November 14 Forget Canada: The Best Places To Flee Trump's America Asian Market News Taiwan Stock Market May Snap Losing Streak Singapore Bourse Likely To Crack Resistance At 2,800 Points Malaysia Market May Extend Tuesday's Gains South Korea Shares May Find Traction On Wednesday Sensex Plunges 514 Points On Capital Outflow Worries; Nifty Nears 8,200 Asian Shares Mixed In Cautious Trade Sensex Slumps 385 Points In Early Trade, Nifty Slips Below 8,200 Asian Markets Mostly Higher Amid Cautious Trades Sensex, Nifty Seen Higher Despite Mixed Global Cues More Pain Predicted For Thai Stock Market Have Indonesia Stocks Found Their Floor? Reiterated Economy US Europe Asia Global Economic Calendar Economic Scorecard Fed Members Markets Morning Mkt Analysis US Commentary European Commentary Asian Commentary Canadian Commentary Indian Commentary Commodities Bonds Currencies Politics US World White House Elections Congress General News Forex FX Top Stories Currency Analysis Currency Alerts Economic Calendar Economic Scorecard Health Hot Topics Diet & Fitness Kids Health Men's Health Women's Health Cancer News Drug Development Mental Health Tech Hot Topics Gadgets & Games Mobile Green Tech Entertainment Top Stories TV News Movie News Slide Shows Game of Thrones Music news Pop Rock Classic Rock Rap/Hip-Hop Country Alternative Oldies All Genre Content Licensing Newswires & Feeds Content Syndication Digital Signage Services Radio News Services Premium Emerging Biostocks Under The Radar Short-Term Investor NewsStream Login More Free Content RSS Feeds Search Blog Political Science / Nature Fundamental Analysis Columns Science & Tech Arts & Leisure Politics & Policy Money Commentary   E-MAIL  SHARE FONT-SIZE    Tweet Share Continued Selling Pressure Tipped For KOSPI 10/25/2016 7:00 PM ET The South Korea stock market turned lower again on Tuesday, one session after it had halted the two-day slide in which it had fallen almost 8 points or 0.4 percent. The KOSPI settled just above the 2,035-point plateau, and the market may take further damage on Wednesday. The global forecast for the Asian markets suggests mild consolidation thanks to weak earnings news and economic data, plus a decline in the price of crude oil. The European and U.S. markets were down and the Asian bourses figure to follow suit. The KOSPI finished modestly lower on Tuesday as losses from the technology stocks and cosmetics companies were tempered by support from the financial shares and the automobile producers. For the day, the index shed 10.57 points or 0.52 percent to finish at 2,037.17 after trading between 2,031.25 and 2,042.65. Volume was 294 million shares worth 4.82 trillion won. There were 583 decliners and 232 gainers. Among the actives, Samsung Electronics lost 0.68 percent, while LG Electronics skidded 2.34 percent, Korea Electric Power shed 0.68 percent, AmorePacific plummeted 7.12 percent, SK hynix spiked 2.24 percent, Hyundai Motor advanced 2.6 percent, Kia Motors added 0.73 percent, Shinhan Financial collected 0.46 percent, Lotte Chemical climbed 1.64 percent and Hanjin Shipping tumbled 5.97 percent. The lead from Wall Street is soft as stocks moved lower on Tuesday, although the downside was fairly limited. The S&P 500 fell 8.17 points or 0.38 percent to 2,143.15, while the NASDAQ slid 26.43 points or 0.50 percent to 5,283.40 and the Dow lost 53.76 points or 0.30 percent to 18,169.27. The weakness came as traders reacted to the latest earnings news, with Sonic (SONC) reporting better than expected fiscal Q4 earnings but providing disappointing guidance. Also, Under Amour (UA) said its growth rate was slowing, while Procter & Gamble (PG) reported results that beat estimates. In economic news, the Conference Board noted a bigger than expected drop in consumer confidence in October. Falling crude oil prices also weighed as Dec. WTI oil fell 56 cents or 1.1 percent to $49.96/bbl. by RTT Staff Writer For comments and feedback: editorial@rttnews.com The Most Influential Books In Business Fed Chatterbox: Economic Preview Week of November 14 Forget Canada: The Best Places To Flee Trump's America More Commentary -Global Taiwan Stock Market May Snap Losing Streak Singapore Bourse Likely To Crack Resistance At 2,800 Points Malaysia Market May Extend Tuesday's Gains South Korea Shares May Find Traction On Wednesday Stocks Close Mostly Higher Following Upbeat Retail Sales Data - U.S. Commentary Major Averages Remain Mixed In Mid-Day Trading - U.S. Commentary European Markets Finish Mostly Higher, But Little Changed Overall Nasdaq And S&P 500 Move Higher But Dow Gives Back Ground - U.S. Commentary Stocks May Open Higher On Upbeat Retail Sales Data - U.S. Commentary Wall Street Aims At Higher Opening Sensex Plunges 514 Points On Capital Outflow Worries; Reiterated Economy US Europe Asia Global Economic Calendar Economic Scorecard Fed Members Markets Morning Mkt Analysis US Commentary European Commentary Asian Commentary Canadian Commentary Indian Commentary Commodities Bonds Currencies Politics US World White House Elections Congress General News Forex FX Top Stories Currency Analysis Currency Alerts Economic Calendar Economic Scorecard Health Hot Topics Diet & Fitness Kids Health Men's Health Women's Health Cancer News Drug Development Mental Health Tech Hot Topics Gadgets & Games Mobile Green Tech Entertainment Top Stories TV News Movie News Slide Shows Game of Thrones Music news Pop Rock Classic Rock Rap/Hip-Hop Country Alternative Oldies All Genre Content Licensing Newswires & Feeds Content Syndication Digital Signage Services Radio News Services Premium Emerging Biostocks Under The Radar Short-Term Investor NewsStream Login More Free Content RSS Feeds Search Blog Political Science / Nature Fundamental Analysis Columns Science & Tech Arts & Leisure Politics & Policy Money Asian Market Updates   E-MAIL  SHARE FONT-SIZE    Tweet Share Taiwan Bourse Due For Consolidation 10/25/2016 8:30 PM ET The Taiwan stock market has tracked higher in back-to-back sessions, advancing almost 80 points or 0.9 percent along the way. The Taiwan Stock Exchange now rests just above the 9,385-point plateau, although the market is ripe for profit taking on Wednesday. The global forecast for the Asian markets suggests mild consolidation thanks to weak earnings news and economic data, plus a decline in the price of crude oil. The European and U.S. markets were down and the Asian bourses figure to follow suit. The TSE finished modestly higher on Tuesday following gains from the technology stocks and the financial shares. For the day, the index gained 63.15 points or 0.68 percent to finish at 9,385.65 after trading between 9,334.80 and 9,399.97 on turnover of 64.30 billion Taiwan dollars. Among the actives, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company climbed 1.05 percent, while AU Optronics perked 1.56 percent, Largan Precision tumbled 1.46 percent, Hon Hai Precision advanced 1.78 percent, Pegatron jumped 1.92 percent, MediaTek spiked 2.10 percent, Formosa Petrochemical surged 3.40 percent, Fubon Financial collected 1.00 percent and Cathay Financial added 0.37 percent. The lead from Wall Street is soft as stocks moved lower on Tuesday, although the downside was fairly limited. The S&P 500 fell 8.17 points or 0.38 percent to 2,143.15, while the NASDAQ slid 26.43 points or 0.50 percent to 5,283.40 and the Dow lost 53.76 points or 0.30 percent to 18,169.27. The weakness came as traders reacted to the latest earnings news, with Sonic (SONC) reporting better than expected fiscal Q4 earnings but providing disappointing guidance. Also, Under Amour (UA) said its growth rate was slowing, while Procter & Gamble (PG) reported results that beat estimates. In economic news, the Conference Board noted a bigger than expected drop in consumer confidence in October. Falling crude oil prices also weighed as Dec. Energy Graphics Game Plan Small Business Personal Finance Inspire GO The David Rubenstein Show Sponsored Content Bloomberg About The Company Sign In Sign In Subscribe Tata’s Shock Coup Follows Simmering Rift at India’s Biggest Firm Siddharth Vikram Philip sidyoutwit P R Sanjai talktosanjai George Smith Alexander October 26, 2016 — 12:56 AM EDT Updated on October 26, 2016 — 7:30 AM EDT Share on FacebookShare on Twitter Share on LinkedInShare on RedditShare on Google+E-mailShare on TwitterShare on WhatsApp Tata Heads Kept in the Dark Over Mistry's Departure Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg Group faces $18 billion in writedowns, Mistry tells directors Ratan Tata met group company chiefs to reassure employees Share on FacebookShare on Twitter Share on LinkedInShare on RedditShare on Google+E-mailShare on TwitterShare on WhatsApp The agenda for Monday’s extraordinary board meeting at India’s largest conglomerate contained little hint of what was to come. Tata Sons Ltd. directors were summoned to the group’s fabled Bombay House headquarters to discuss the sale of assets, its moribund U.K. steel business and the group’s legal wrangles with Japan’s NTT Docomo Inc., according to a person with knowledge of the events. But once the meeting started in the wood-paneled boardroom on the fourth floor, it took a different turn. Under a portrait of the formidable J R D Tata, the board wrested back chairmanship of the steel-to-software business empire for 78-year-old Ratan Tata, ousting his protege Cyrus Mistry, 48, in a coup that stunned India’s business community. Mistry said he was shocked at the nature of his dismissal and described the board meeting as illegal and invalid, according to an e-mail he sent to Tata directors. Ratan Tata had met Mistry earlier on Monday to present him with options, according to three people with knowledge of the matter, who asked not to be identified because the meeting was private. "I have to say that the Board of Directors has not covered itself with glory," Mistry said in the letter, a copy of which was seen by Bloomberg News. "To ‘replace’ your Chairman without so much as a word of explanation and without affording him an opportunity to defending himself in a summary manner must be unique in the annals of corporate history." In the e-mail, Mistry also warned that the tea-to-software giant may face 1.18 trillion rupees ($18 billion) in writedowns because of five unprofitable businesses he inherited. The rift had been brewing for months, said people who work with senior Tata executives and asked not to be named because the matter is private. It was a clash of styles, a feeling that Mistry, handpicked by Tata, wasn’t adhering to the traditional values of a company that had previously been led by a person related to the Tata family. Key to the showdown was a $1.17 billion legal battle with former partner Docomo over an Indian telecom venture. Docomo is trying to enforce a London Court of International Arbitration decision ordering Tata Sons to pay the sum for failing to uphold a contract. That venture was created during Ratan Tata’s 21-year period at the helm, and Mistry’s handling of the matter was seen by some as an erosion of the Tata Sons ethic of honoring commitments, according to the people. “The biggest challenge for an organization is planning for succession, especially following the tenure of a very successful CEO,” said Vijay Govindarajan, a professor at Dartmouth University’s Tuck School of Business. “The current leadership crisis is an unwanted distraction.” Mistry’s handling of troubles at other group businesses were also causing concern, according to the people, including the break-up of Tata Steel’s European empire, which Ratan Tata helped acquire. Spokesmen for Ratan Tata and Mistry declined to comment. For a QuickTake Q&A on Tata Group, click here. Yet if Mistry’s way of doing things was rankling the old guard, he also had successes in an increasingly difficult business climate. Ratan Tata had swelled group revenues more than 60-fold to $100 billion with a campaign of expansion abroad that included the troubled European steelmaker Corus Group Plc and marquee brands such as Land Rover, Jaguar, Tetley tea and New York’s Pierre hotel. With the slowdown in China dragging on global trade and Brexit concerns further damping European operations, Mistry was trying to unwind some of that growth and pay back part of the debt Tata had built up to pay for the acquisitions. And while the steel and power businesses were losing money, Tata Consultancy Services Ltd., the group’s largest unit, has pushed into cloud computing and digital services to weather lackluster global IT spending, beating analysts’ estimates in the process. "I am stunned,” said S. Manikutty, a former professor at the Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad, who closely tracks Indian conglomerates and family businesses. “It was completely unexpected because Mr. Mistry was trying to remove important cobwebs from the Tata stable.” That didn’t save him. The day after his ouster, the corridors of Bombay House, Tata Group’s austere headquarters for 92 years in downtown Mumbai, were quiet, with most staff still in shock at the news. Traffic jammed the street outside, while reporters, TV crews and onlookers thronged the building. Media Speculation As rumors flew and media speculation mounted, Ratan Tata called together the chief executives of the group’s businesses to calm the ship. There would be continuity in all branches of the business without any issues, he told them in a 25-minute gathering, according to an executive who was present. Tata said he was keen to honor decisions made by Mistry, the person said. To read a Gadfly column on the Tata ouster, click here Ratan Tata is the latest in a long line of so-called boomerang CEOs who retook control after stepping down or being ousted. The late Steve Jobs revived Apple Inc. after more than a decade in the wilderness, A. G. Lafley made a two-year return performance at Procter & Gamble Co., Howard Schultz came back to give Starbucks Corp. another shot, and Narayana Murthy made a brief return as executive chairman at Tata’s IT rival Infosys Ltd. Now Ratan Tata’s search for a successor is back where it started. After grooming Mistry for a year before he took over, Tata and four other prominent leaders -- Venu Srinivasan, Amit Chandra, Ronen Sen and Kumar Bhattacharyya -- are part of the panel formed to find a new chairman within four months. For a story on Ratan Tata’s investment after stepping down in 2012, click here “This will mean another period of uncertainty to Tata stakeholders,” said Morgen Witzel, author of “Tata: The Evolution of a Corporate Brand.” He called the pledge to find a new leader within four months, “a heroic undertaking, given how long it took them to choose Mr. Mistry in the first place.” Tata himself has said that it’s not easy to spot a true leader. At a meeting with young entrepreneurs in Singapore in late March, he was asked about the qualities that make a chief. He responded that it wasn’t easy to tell how someone would respond until they were in the job. “The final test is crisis that one faces,” he answered at the time, speaking generally. “Someone who deals with that crisis with his sleeves rolled up, as against those who hold on, is finally the mark of a real leader.” Before it's here, it's on the Bloomberg Terminal. ENGLISH MENA - ENGLISH UAE - ENGLISH KSA - ENGLISH الشرَقُ الأَوْسَط الإمارات السعودية THOMSON REUTERS PRODUCTS Solutions for Corporations Solutions for Emerging Business Solutions for Financial Institutions Solutions for Governments Solutions for Professionals REGISTER LOGIN Advertisement Earnings, consumer confidence weigh on markets 25 Oct 2016 Stocks were unable to hold onto early gains as investors reacted to lackluster earnings news and a pullback in consumer sentiment measured by the Conference Board. Jeanne Yurman reports. Video Transcript Apple reported a third straight quarterly decline in iPhone sales, its top selling product after the bell Tuesday, sending revenue slightly below Wall Street targets. Lackluster earnings news and a disappointing read on consumer confidence sent U.S. stocks lower on the day. Companies from 3M to General Motors gave cautious guidance - a potential weight on stocks says Keith Bliss of Cuttone an Company. (SOUNDBITE) KEITH BLISS, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT, CUTTONE AND COMPANY (ENGLISH) SAYING: So if they give us unfavorable reports number one and then poor guidance number two, we're going to continue to see this overhang on the market. General Motors quarterly results beat Street estimates but shares closed lower amid fears that slowing U.S. vehicle sales will undercut future profits. Consumer products giant Procter & Gamble's bottom line came in better than expected helped in part by cost-cutting. While Under Armour shares posted steep losses after the company said its growth rate will be slower than expected going forward. A federal judge approved the biggest auto scandal settlement in history. Volkswagen will pay nearly $15 billion for using software that cheated emissions tests. U.S. home prices continued to climb in August. An index from S&P CoreLogic Case Shiller showed more than five percent increase from the same time last year. In Europe, a mixed finish as investors weighed earnings news on both sides of the Atlantic. more from markets   Multimedia gallery The U.S.-Mexico border now gallery Supermoon of the century AUDIO Measuring HR effectiveness in the region AUDIO Brandy Scott's TED talk on happiness AUDIO How e-commerce will succeed in the Middle East AUDIO Why success is so closely tied to happiness Advertisement Most Popular Videos 'Supermoon' spectacle wows sky-watchers 1 day ago - Reuters Videos Samsung buys Harman in $8 bln smart car push 2 days ago - Reuters Videos Goldman Sachs considers Frankfurt move 11 Nov 2016 - Reuters Videos Advertisement About zawya Contact us Copyright © 2016 Zawya. The Stock Exchange of Thailand settled just above the 1,505-point plateau, although investors may lock in gains on Wednesday. The global forecast for the Asian markets suggests mild consolidation thanks to weak earnings news and economic data, plus a decline in the price of crude oil. The European and U.S. markets were down and the Asian bourses figure to follow suit. The SET finished modestly higher as gains from the cement stocks and energy producers were capped by weakness from the financial sector. For the day, the index climbed 6.10 points or 0.41 percent to finish at 1,506.47 after trading between 1,496.66 and 1,508.89. Volume was 9.545 billion shares worth 47.446 billion baht. There were 573 gainers and 567 decliners, with 353 stocks finishing unchanged. Among the actives, Advanced Info was unchanged, while coal miner Banpu shed 2.08 percent, Bangkok bank lost 0.92 percent, Kasikornbank fell 0.85 percent, energy giant PTT added 0.57 percent, PTT Exploration and Production skidded 1.46 percent, PTT Global Chemical gained 0.42 percent, Siam Commercial bank dipped 0.34 percent and Siam Concrete advanced 0.39 percent. The lead from Wall Street is soft as stocks moved lower on Tuesday, although the downside was fairly limited. The S&P 500 fell 8.17 points or 0.38 percent to 2,143.15, while the NASDAQ slid 26.43 points or 0.50 percent to 5,283.40 and the Dow lost 53.76 points or 0.30 percent to 18,169.27. The weakness came as traders reacted to the latest earnings news, with Sonic (SONC) reporting better than expected fiscal Q4 earnings but providing disappointing guidance. Also, Under Amour (UA) said its growth rate was slowing, while Procter & Gamble (PG) reported results that beat estimates. In economic news, the Conference Board noted a bigger than expected drop in consumer confidence in October. Falling crude oil prices also weighed as Dec. WTI oil fell 56 cents or 1.1 percent to $49.96/bbl. by RTT Staff Writer For comments and feedback: editorial@rttnews.com The Most Influential Books In Business Fed Chatterbox: Economic Preview Week of November 14 Forget Canada: The Best Places To Flee Trump's America More Commentary -Global Taiwan Stock Market May Snap Losing Streak Singapore Bourse Likely To Crack Resistance At 2,800 Points Malaysia Market May Extend Tuesday's Gains South Korea Shares May Find Traction On Wednesday Stocks Close Mostly Higher Following Upbeat Retail Sales Data - U.S. Commentary Major Averages Remain Mixed In Mid-Day Trading - U.S. Commentary European Markets Finish Mostly Higher, But Little Changed Overall Nasdaq And S&P 500 Move Higher But Dow Gives Back Ground - U.S. Commentary Stocks May Open Higher On Upbeat Retail Sales Data - U.S. Commentary Wall Street Aims At Higher Opening Sensex Plunges 514 Points On Capital Outflow Worries; Reiterated Economy US Europe Asia Global Economic Calendar Economic Scorecard Fed Members Markets Morning Mkt Analysis US Commentary European Commentary Asian Commentary Canadian Commentary Indian Commentary Commodities Bonds Currencies Politics US World White House Elections Congress General News Forex FX Top Stories Currency Analysis Currency Alerts Economic Calendar Economic Scorecard Health Hot Topics Diet & Fitness Kids Health Men's Health Women's Health Cancer News Drug Development Mental Health Tech Hot Topics Gadgets & Games Mobile Green Tech Entertainment Top Stories TV News Movie News Slide Shows Game of Thrones Music news Pop Rock Classic Rock Rap/Hip-Hop Country Alternative Oldies All Genre Content Licensing Newswires & Feeds Content Syndication Digital Signage Services Radio News Services Premium Emerging Biostocks Under The Radar Short-Term Investor NewsStream Login More Free Content RSS Feeds Search Blog Political Science / Nature Fundamental Analysis Columns Science & Tech Arts & Leisure Politics & Policy Money Asian Market Updates   E-MAIL  SHARE FONT-SIZE    Tweet Share Singapore Bourse May Extend Tuesday's Losses 10/25/2016 8:00 PM ET The Singapore stock market headed south again on Tuesday, one session after it had ended the two-day losing streak in which it had surrendered almost 15 points or 0.5 percent. The Straits Times Index slipped just beneath the 2,855-point plateau, and the losses figure to accelerate on Wednesday. The global forecast for the Asian markets suggests mild consolidation thanks to weak earnings news and economic data, plus a decline in the price of crude oil. The European and U.S. markets were down and the Asian bourses figure to follow suit. The STI finished slightly lower on Tuesday following weakness from the properties, gains from the plantations and mixed performances from the financials and industrials. For the day, the index dipped 2.63 points or 0.09 percent to finish at 2,854.05 after trading between 2,851.26 and 2,860.74 on turnover of 713.9 million Singapore dollars. Among the actives, Golden Agri-Resources surged 5.26 percent, while CapitaLand Commercial Trust dropped 1.24 percent, SembCorp Marine tumbled 1.13 percent, Hutchison Port Holdings skidded 1.11 percent, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding gained 0.67 percent, Thai Beverage perked 0.52 percent, CapitaLand slid 0.32 percent, DBS Group fell 0.40 percent and Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation collected 0.58 percent. The lead from Wall Street is soft as stocks moved lower on Tuesday, although the downside was fairly limited. The S&P 500 fell 8.17 points or 0.38 percent to 2,143.15, while the NASDAQ slid 26.43 points or 0.50 percent to 5,283.40 and the Dow lost 53.76 points or 0.30 percent to 18,169.27. The weakness came as traders reacted to the latest earnings news, with Sonic (SONC) reporting better than expected fiscal Q4 earnings but providing disappointing guidance. Also, Under Amour (UA) said its growth rate was slowing, while Procter & Gamble (PG) reported results that beat estimates. In economic news, the Conference Board noted a bigger than expected drop in consumer confidence in October. Falling crude oil prices also weighed as Dec. WTI oil fell 56 cents or 1.1 percent to $49.96/bbl. Closer to home, Singapore will provide September data for industrial production later today; in August, output was flat on month and up 0.1 percent on year. by RTT Staff Writer For comments and feedback: editorial@rttnews.com Market Analysis The Most Influential Books In Business Fed Chatterbox: Economic Preview Week of November 14 Forget Canada: The Best Places To Flee Trump's America Asian Market News Taiwan Stock Market May Snap Losing Streak Singapore Bourse Likely To Crack Resistance At 2,800 Points Malaysia Market May Extend Tuesday's Gains South Korea Shares May Find Traction On Wednesday Sensex Plunges 514 Points On Capital Outflow Worries; Nifty Nears 8,200 Asian Shares Mixed In Cautious Trade Sensex Slumps 385 Points In Early Trade, Nifty Slips Below 8,200 Asian Markets Mostly Higher Amid Cautious Trades Sensex, Nifty Seen Higher Despite Mixed Global Cues More Pain Predicted For Thai Stock Market Have Indonesia Stocks Found Their Floor? The Hang Seng Index settled just above the 23,565-point plateau, and the losses may accelerate on Wednesday. The global forecast for the Asian markets suggests mild consolidation thanks to weak earnings news and economic data, plus a decline in the price of crude oil. The European and U.S. markets were down and the Asian bourses figure to follow suit. The Hang Seng finished slightly lower on Tuesday as losses from the financials and oil companies were tempered by support from the casinos. For the day, the index lost 38.97 points or 0.17 percent to finish at 23,565.11 after trading between 23,506.64 and 23,631.34. Among the actives, Belle International Holdings plummeted 9.14 percent, while Galaxy Entertainment surged 2.78 percent, Sands China spiked 1.59 percent, CITIC skidded 1.04 percent, Bank of China shed 0.89 percent, Industrial and Commercial bank of China retreated 0.42 percent, HSBC eased 0.25 percent, China Resources Land advanced 0.90 percent, Ping An picked up 0.85 percent and China Petroleum and Chemical (Sinopec) skidded 0.67 percent. The lead from Wall Street is soft as stocks moved lower on Tuesday, although the downside was fairly limited. The S&P 500 fell 8.17 points or 0.38 percent to 2,143.15, while the NASDAQ slid 26.43 points or 0.50 percent to 5,283.40 and the Dow lost 53.76 points or 0.30 percent to 18,169.27. The weakness came as traders reacted to the latest earnings news, with Sonic (SONC) reporting better than expected fiscal Q4 earnings but providing disappointing guidance. Also, Under Amour (UA) said its growth rate was slowing, while Procter & Gamble (PG) reported results that beat estimates. In economic news, the Conference Board noted a bigger than expected drop in consumer confidence in October. Falling crude oil prices also weighed as Dec. WTI oil fell 56 cents or 1.1 percent to $49.96/bbl. by RTT Staff Writer For comments and feedback: editorial@rttnews.com Market Analysis The Most Influential Books In Business Fed Chatterbox: Economic Preview Week of November 14 Forget Canada: The Best Places To Flee Trump's America Asian Market News Taiwan Stock Market May Snap Losing Streak Singapore Bourse Likely To Crack Resistance At 2,800 Points Malaysia Market May Extend Tuesday's Gains South Korea Shares May Find Traction On Wednesday Sensex Plunges 514 Points On Capital Outflow Worries; Nifty Nears 8,200 Asian Shares Mixed In Cautious Trade Sensex Slumps 385 Points In Early Trade, Nifty Slips Below 8,200 Asian Markets Mostly Higher Amid Cautious Trades Sensex, Nifty Seen Higher Despite Mixed Global Cues More Pain Predicted For Thai Stock Market Have Indonesia Stocks Found Their Floor? Reiterated Economy US Europe Asia Global Economic Calendar Economic Scorecard Fed Members Markets Morning Mkt Analysis US Commentary European Commentary Asian Commentary Canadian Commentary Indian Commentary Commodities Bonds Currencies Politics US World White House Elections Congress General News Forex FX Top Stories Currency Analysis Currency Alerts Economic Calendar Economic Scorecard Health Hot Topics Diet & Fitness Kids Health Men's Health Women's Health Cancer News Drug Development Mental Health Tech Hot Topics Gadgets & Games Mobile Green Tech Entertainment Top Stories TV News Movie News Slide Shows Game of Thrones Music news Pop Rock Classic Rock Rap/Hip-Hop Country Alternative Oldies All Genre Content Licensing Newswires & Feeds Content Syndication Digital Signage Services Radio News Services Premium Emerging Biostocks Under The Radar Short-Term Investor NewsStream Login More Free Content RSS Feeds Search Blog Political Science / Nature Fundamental Analysis Columns Science & Tech Arts & Leisure Politics & Policy Money Asian Market Updates   E-MAIL  SHARE FONT-SIZE    Tweet Share Win Streak May End For China Stock Market 10/25/2016 9:00 PM ET The China stock market has moved higher in three straight trading days, gathering more than 45 points or 1.5 percent along the way. The Shanghai Composite Index now rests just above the 3,130-point plateau, although investors figure to cash in on Wednesday. The global forecast for the Asian markets suggests mild consolidation thanks to weak earnings news and economic data, plus a decline in the price of crude oil. The European and U.S. markets were down and the Asian bourses figure to follow suit. The SCI finished slightly higher on Tuesday following gains from the financial shares and resource stocks. For the day, the index added 3.69 points or 0.12 percent to finish at 3,131.94 after trading between 3,121.05 and 3,132.50. The Shenzhen Component Index gained 0.27 percent to end at 10,871.50. Among the actives, Agricultural Bank of China collected 0.32 percent, while Bank of China gained 0.29 percent, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China picked up 0.45 percent, China Life shed 0.50 percent, China Shenhua advanced 0.40 percent, Baoshan Iron spiked 2.15 percent, China Coal Energy soared 7 percent and China Unicom slipped 1.13 percent. The lead from Wall Street is soft as stocks moved lower on Tuesday, although the downside was fairly limited. The S&P 500 fell 8.17 points or 0.38 percent to 2,143.15, while the NASDAQ slid 26.43 points or 0.50 percent to 5,283.40 and the Dow lost 53.76 points or 0.30 percent to 18,169.27. The weakness came as traders reacted to the latest earnings news, with Sonic (SONC) reporting better than expected fiscal Q4 earnings but providing disappointing guidance. Also, Under Amour (UA) said its growth rate was slowing, while Procter & Gamble (PG) reported results that beat estimates. In economic news, the Conference Board noted a bigger than expected drop in consumer confidence in October. Falling crude oil prices also weighed as Dec. WTI oil fell 56 cents or 1.1 percent to $49.96/bbl. by RTT Staff Writer For comments and feedback: editorial@rttnews.com Market Analysis The Most Influential Books In Business Fed Chatterbox: Economic Preview Week of November 14 Forget Canada: The Best Places To Flee Trump's America Asian Market News Taiwan Stock Market May Snap Losing Streak Singapore Bourse Likely To Crack Resistance At 2,800 Points Malaysia Market May Extend Tuesday's Gains South Korea Shares May Find Traction On Wednesday Sensex Plunges 514 Points On Capital Outflow Worries; Nifty Nears 8,200 Asian Shares Mixed In Cautious Trade Sensex Slumps 385 Points In Early Trade, Nifty Slips Below 8,200 Asian Markets Mostly Higher Amid Cautious Trades Sensex, Nifty Seen Higher Despite Mixed Global Cues More Pain Predicted For Thai Stock Market Have Indonesia Stocks Found Their Floor? Q3 inflation rises to 0.7%, but economists remain worried about soft core inflation Battle for market share is hurting Coles, where sales growth has slowed again Ardent Leisure shares plunge further following tragic Dreamworld accident No respite for Bega Cheese as shares extend slide following gloomy JV outlook Will NAB cut its dividend tomorrow? Goldman and Citi reckon it will happen Iron ore price jumps more than 4% above $US60, but this time it's not speculation Sort posts by Newest Oldest 4:47pm on 26 Oct 2016 That's it for Markets Live today. Thanks for reading and your comments. See you all again tomorrow morning from 9. 4:34pm on 26 Oct 2016 Shares plunged at the open and then showed no signs of a recovery as investors sniffed the air and decided it was time to sell. The ASX 200 index shed 83 points or 1.5 per cent to 5360, with only one in 10 constituents managing to finish in the green. The Aussie dollar maintained its post-CPI gains at 76.9 US cents after starting the session at more like 76.5 US cents. A poor lead from Wall St and a falling oil price set a sour mood early before an underwhelming sales update from supermarket giant Wesfarmers confirmed that this was not going to be a good day on the boards. The owner of Coles dropped a hefty 5.7 per cent - its worst day since the GFC! The big four banks all fell more or less in lockstep, adding to the sense of indiscriminate selling. In the end they were all lower by between 0.9 per cent and 1.4 per cent. NAB fell 1.2 per cent ahead of its annual profit result tomorrow. Ardent Leisure plunged 15 per cent a day after news broke of fatalities at its Dreamworld park on the Gold Coast. Bega Cheese also extended its losses following yesterday's trading update, dropping 3 per cent. Investors rushed to sell associated names: Bellamy's dropped 5.7 per cent and Blackmores 6.3 per cent. But a stock that has come under pressure of late, Ramsay Health Care, managed to climb 1.5 per cent for a second session. Some dividend darlings also got whacked: Transurban by 2.4 per cent and Sydney Airport 3 per cent. Falling oil prices put the energy sector under pressure, dropping 2.5 per cent as a group. BHP lost 1.5 per cent. But iron ore, coal and gold miners were feeling the love and were rare bright spots. Rio climbed 1.7 per cent and Fortescue 0.9 per cent after the price of the bulk commodity jumped 4.5 per cent on Tuesday night and as analysts suggested the rally looked based on fundamentals. 3:55pm on 26 Oct 2016 ASX aspirant Autosports Group's' initial public offering is on track to price at $2.40 a share, equating to a multiple of 17.2 times forecast net profit, The AFR's Street Talk column has revealed. It's understood the book was well-covered to price at $2.40, however, the final decision is in the hands of the Tom Pockett-chaired company. If the deal is priced at $2.40, it means the company has raised $160.1 million for a $482.4 million market capitalisation.  Sponsor brokers Macquarie Capital and UBS started allocations to fund managers this afternoon.  Autosports had been seeking to raise up to $160.1 million at $2.10 to $2.40 a share. The price range was set at 15-times to 17.2-times forecast profit after tax and amortisation. Car dealership owner Autosports Group makes about 40 per cent of its revenue from Audi cars.  Photo: Samuel Hall 3:50pm on 26 Oct 2016 Movements in sharemarkets are fuelled by information and ideas. Often it's the information and ideas of broker analysts, who feed their clients with stock recommendations, earnings forecasts and trading strategies, that move the market the most. For decades, they have sat at the nerve centre of investment banks. But the "sell-side" research model is being attacked from all sides. As brokerage trading profits slide, well-resourced research teams are being trimmed back rapidly to manage costs. Meanwhile, active fund managers are also under pressure over fees, as they compete with low-cost passive funds that charge much smaller fees – and have no use for any research. Larger institutions are also reviewing their trading arrangements to ensure the cost of brokerage means they're not overpaying for research when they reward brokers via trading commissions. But an even bigger threat is emerging. New rules to be introduced in Europe, as part of the MiFId II reforms, will force buy-side funds to formally "unbundle" the price they pay to execute trades, and the price they pay for research. That could be devastating. Fund managers, traders, analysts and banking heads are asking whether this reform will spread to the rest of the world. Those fears may be well founded. AFR Street Talk reported on Wednesday that Colonial First State's Stewart Investors will now start paying for equity research out of its own pocket. Here's more at the AFR ($) Sell-side research faces new threats. Photo: Christopher Pearce 3:49pm on 26 Oct 2016 After a long awaited $361 million takeover offer from South African-based discounter Steinhoff, shareholders in furniture retailer Fantastic Holdings were ready to crack open the champagne at the company's annual meeting today. However, major shareholder and chairman Julian Tertini put a dampener on the party mood, telling shareholders there were risks to Steinhoff's $3.50 a share offer and the company intended to press on with its strategy in case the scheme of arrangement did not proceed. "Your board is unanimously in favour of the proposal but we recognise there is a long process to work through still and there are risks to it proceeding," said Mr Tertini. ​"Accordingly, we are continuing to run the business in the ordinary and usual manner," he said. In the first four months of 2017, total sales from continuing businesses rose 6 per cent, despite supply chain disruptions following the collapse of a major supplier. Mr Tertini also dismissed the likelihood of a rival bid, even though the company and key institutional shareholders were approached by private equity investors earlier this year. "I confirm that there are no other offers or discussions happening with other parties," he said. Shareholders are also understood to have lobbied for Mr Tertini to stand down as chairman in favour of RCG Corp chairman Ivan Hammerschlag, who bought shares in Fantastic earlier this year at around $1.90. However, sources said Mr Tertini was reluctant to stand aside for Mr Hammerschlag, who succeeded him as boss of Freedom Furniture in the 1990s. Mr Tertini incurred a protest vote at the AGM, with 29 per cent of shares voted against his re-election as a non-executive director because he is not seen as independent. Shareholders said Mr Tertini's comments were surprising, but believe he was trying to encourage minority investors to vote in favour of the Steinhoff proposal amid talk that the shares were worth closer to $4 if franking credits were taken into account. The shares last fetched $3.45. "There are some rumblings out there and one or two shareholders are agitating for a bit more  -  if this board was not so complex we'd be pushing for a higher price," one fund manager said. Fantastic chairman and major shareholder Julian Tertini has warned shareholders there are risks to Steinhoff's $361 million takeover offer but no rival bidders. Photo: Rob Homer Back to top 3:33pm on 26 Oct 2016 Perth housing is showing signs of recovery and first-time buyers are returning to Brisbane, diversified property group Stockland says in its first 2017 quarter update.  While Stockland's residential division kicked off the year strongly, it was its retail division that shone.  "Our focus on growing asset returns, broadening our customer base and taking advantage of supportive market conditions has resulted in a strong September quarter," chief executive Mark Steinert said.  In residential, the group achieved a record number of deposits for its residential lots and townhouses - it collected 2301 net deposits up from 1,557 at the same time last year.  "We see continued high demand in the Sydney and Melbourne markets and an encouraging return of first home buyers in south east Queensland, who are taking advantage of the Queensland First Home Owners' Grant, which was recently increased to $20,000," residential chief executive Andrew Whitson said. "We remain on track to achieve more than 6000 residential settlements for the full year and see constructive signs for an elongated property cycle." Sydney and Melbourne remained its strongest markets with the medium density sector performing well. The medium density market continues to be in short supply but a move to expedite the medium density development by the NSW government should improve conditions.  Overall, Stockland expects a more moderate "sales run rate" for the rest of the year and extended settlement periods for both Sydney and Melbourne. Importantly it is starting to see "early signs of a stabilisation in the WA market".  Stockland's retail business was the biggest contributor to group earnings and the strongest retail categories were communications technology, food catering and casual dining and retail services. Sales for the quarter lifted by 2.4 per cent, with comparable specialty sales up 1.1 per cent versus last year. Stockland is seeking approval to build 530 new apartments in three buildings in Brisbane's inner west suburb of Toowong.  3:19pm on 26 Oct 2016 Stockbrokers are slashing their estimates of fair value for Bega Cheese shares. We've already heard from analysts at Bell Potter (see post at 10:40am), and Morgans number crunchers have also raised the fact that the cheese maker's infant formula venture with Blackmores has been discounting product "heavily in what is an already overcrowded category". Bell Potter has slashed to $5.19 from $6.32 its 12-month price target for the company's shares as Morgans cut its target to $4.90 from $6.20 before Bega Cheese's annual general meeting Tuesday where the processor warned of problems with the entry into the infant milk formula market. The stock last fetched $5.20. Both of the analysts were also cautious over milk production volumes across south east Australia down 11 per cent so far this year. "The loss of the Coles private label contract from January 2017 to Murray Goulburn will impact FY17, despite the win of the much smaller Woolworths contract," Morgans told its clients. Morningstar's Chris Kallos expects it may take time for the venture to gain traction in the infant milk formula market. "While [Blackmores] is well established in the Australian vitamin and supplement market given its long history, Blackmores is a relative newcomer to the infant formula space," Morningstar's Kallos told clients this morning. "Notwithstanding the general competitive and regulatory risks associated with building a business in China, we remain positive on the commercial opportunity." And at least one analyst reckons the recent share price pain could be a good opportunity to take a punt on. The market has "overreacted", Saxo Capital Markets strategist Kay Van-Petersen said. "Bega Cheese is in a class of one in the Australian market and one of the few pure plays on the Asia protein trade; that is, feeding the emerging middle classes of the Asian economies," he said, pointing to technical trading indicators that suggests "we are in oversold territory". Van-Petersen said he was long at $5.17 per share, with a stop-loss trigger at $4.60, or 11 per cent below. He added that the "trade horizon" looks like three to six months. 2:58pm on 26 Oct 2016 We mentioned earlier that the ASX is the region's underperformer. What's going on? Sentiment around the region has been hit by a mix of falling oil prices and worries about US earnings after Apple and a few others underwhelmed. And then it only took some disappointing updates from Wesfarmers and Ainsworth to exacerbate the local gloom.  "Today the market looks like it just wanted to lie down, it looks fatigued," says Frank Villante, chief investment officer at Celeste Investment Management, citing poor AGM updates as well as political uncertainties around the US election as contributing to the selloff. "It looks like a culmination of worries that have just manifest at one point. But I don't think there's one thing in particular that's sending the market down today," he said.  "The main trend that's coming out of AGM season is that it's really tough out there, it's a real grind," he said. "Most people think the US election will go a particular way, but everyone's a bit nervous in a post-Brexit context. What people thought would be obvious, often is not." The main trend coming out of AGM updates is that it's still a grind out there for companies, Frank Villante says.  Photo: Christopher Pearce 2:42pm on 26 Oct 2016 It's going to be a "tough" earnings season for Australia's biggest banks, analysts say. Full-year results due from three of the lenders -- starting with NAB tomorrow -- are poised to show that a record-breaking run of profits is coming to an end amid higher funding costs, lower interest margins and rising bad-debt charges. ANZ may report its lowest cash profit in four years, while Westpac's may be little changed, analyst surveys by Bloomberg indicate. The lenders all reported weaker-than-expected cash profit in the first half, the first time in at least a decade that three of the nation's largest lenders missed estimates at the same time, according to Bloomberg. "Its likely to be a tough half," Goldman Sachs analysts Andrew Lyons and Ashley Dalziell wrote in an Oct. 14 note to clients. "We expect margin contraction to feature." The following are the average full-year cash profit forecasts for each bank, according to a Bloomberg poll of 14 analysts: ANZ: $6.25b, down from $7.22b in fiscal 2015 Westpac: $7.83b, little changed from A$7.82b NAB: $6.51b, up from $5.84b; boosted by sale of life-insurance business CBA, the nation's largest lender, has a June fiscal year, rather than the September-end of its competitors. It's due to give a first-quarter trading update on Nov. 8. The banks' net interest margins, a key measure of lending profitability, are already at an eight-year low and analysts expect these to remain under pressure amid a rise in wholesale funding costs and intense political pressure on lenders to pass on record-low interest rates to mortgage holders. The median margin of the four banks is 2 per cent, compared to 3.1 per cent for large US banks, data compiled by Bloomberg show. Mortgages account for about two-thirds of the big four banks' loan books, on average. The nation's fixed-income investors now cite property-market exposure as the greatest risk to bank credit quality over the next year, Fitch Ratings said in an October survey. That augurs poorly for bad-loan charges. Having stayed low for years, those costs have started to drag on earnings as the end of the mining boom and New Zealand's milk crisis pressures loan repayments from the resources and dairy industries. In the first half of the year, collective impairment charges for the four big banks hit $2.5 billion, the highest level since the first half of 2010. Given the pressures faced by the banks, one focus this earnings season will be whether they can maintain high dividend-payout ratios without compromising the capital reserves demanded by regulators. ANZ cut its payout to shareholders in May for the first time since 2009. NAB and Westpac currently have payout ratios of at least 80 per cent. The six biggest lenders in Canada, which has the most profitable banks in the developed world, have an average payout ratio of 43 per cent, data compiled by Bloomberg show. Citigroup analyst Craig Williams reckons the two Australian banks will reduce dividends when they report their results, according to an Oct. 14 note. Goldman Sachs is also expecting NAB to cut. Lower dividends "would be a pragmatic step given payout ratios are now at unsustainably high levels," said Omkar Joshi, analyst at Watermark Funds Management. 2:21pm on 26 Oct 2016 Here are economist reactions to the surprise rise in headline inflation, but mostly on the still sluggish core numbers and the implications for the RBA Michael Blythe, CBA: Our view before today's numbers was that an underlying CPI rise of 0.3 per cent or less in Q3 would leave inflation trapped at the very low rates that contributed to the May and August rate cuts. As such we continue to expect the RBA to cut the cash rate to 1.25 per cent at the November Board meeting. Although we hold this view without great conviction. There is no "smoking gun" on which to hang a rate cut decision. Josh Williamson, Citi: It's important to note that the drivers of the higher-than-expected Q3 result were mostly negative supply shocks rather than representing the start of cyclical reflation. For example, the 20 per cent fruits and vegetables price rise was the result of flooding in major growing areas and the 5.4 per cent electricity price rise was from major supply outages. These events are temporary boosts to the level of inflation but shouldn't have lasting influences on the CPI or inflationary expectations. There remains a good case for further easing by the RBA, but other macro developments including higher commodity prices could reduce the urgency for a near-term rate cut.  Ivan Colhoun, NAB: The RBA is likely to leave rates unchanged in the next few months at least as it continues to monitor developments in the labour market and the flow through of previous interest rate cuts. Recent rises in commodity prices should provide some boost to sentiment in mining and WA, Queensland and the Northern Territory. Our focus in the short term is more with a possible slowing in momentum in the NSW economy than the low quarterly CPI core measures. Medium term, we remain worried that economic growth in 2018 may require further stimulus to be applied in the second half of 2017. Su-Lin Ong, RBC: The latest Q3 inflation report confirmed a subdued inflation environment across a number of measures with core inflation firmly entrenched sub target. In line with the RBA's forecasts and coupled with a mixed activity picture, this is likely to keep the RBA on the sidelines for some time although its longer-term inflation forecasts, which will remain unchanged in next week's quarterly statement on monetary policy, remain consistent with an implicit, albeit mild, easing bias. Jo Masters, ANZ: The RBA would likely be disquieted by the soft tone for underlying inflation. On this data, it is too early to conclude that disinflationary pressures are abating or even stabilising. Today's data are likely to see the RBA downgrade its inflation profile slightly in next week's SoMP. That said, we doubt the RBA would mechanically respond by cutting rates but rather would wait and closely monitor developments in inflation and wages as well as housing and the labour market over the coming months. Annette Beacher, TD Securities: The Q3 (core inflation) outcome was literally between TD's slight downward bias at 1.5 per cent and the market's 1.6 per cent, but bang on the RBA's 1.5 per cent projection as per its August Statement on Monetary Policy. There is no smoking gun for a cut next week. We see no need for the Bank to change its inflation outlook for next week's November SoMP and hence doesn't provide a discernible trigger to ease in the near term. Rahul Bajoria, Barclays: We think higher headline inflation is driven by temporary factors (adverse weather conditions), which pushed up fresh food prices. Underlying inflation pressures remain low. That said, given that Australia's economic outlook appears resilient to external shocks, and unless there is significant AUD appreciation, we think the RBA sees no urgency to ease further. The OIS market also currently prices in very low probability of RBA easing by December (8 per cent). We continue to expect the RBA to stay on hold through 2016.  Tom Kennedy, JPMorgan: We believe that the decline in inflation in recent quarters is too large for the RBA to ignore, with additional easing expected to be forthcoming in 1H17. Indeed, both headline and core inflation continue to track materially below the mid-point of the RBA's target band, with today's deceleration in the core measure a particular concern. While Australia's activity indicators remain decent, the weak inflation backdrop means the central bank is increasingly sensitive to any future wobbles in the data. As such, we retain our forecast that the RBA will lower the cash rate by a cumulative 50bp in the first half of 2017. Paul Bloxham, HSBC: This rate of underlying inflation would typically be low enough to see the RBA cut the cash rate further in response to the result. However, there are a number of differences this time around: 1.The RBA has already cut its cash rate by 50bp since May, in response to the downside surprise it got to its inflation forecasts back in April. 2. Today's numbers were not a downside surprise to the RBA's current set of published forecasts which see underlying inflation at 1.5% in Q4 2016. 3. The RBA has recently increasingly emphasised the 'flexible' nature of its inflation target, noting that inflation is often outside of the target band but it is the average over time that matters. 4. Growth is currently running at an above trend pace, which should help to lift inflation over time. 5. Commodity prices have lifted, with a particularly sharp rise in coal prices in recent months, which should also support a lift in local incomes, corporate profits, wages growth and thus inflation, over time. Back to top 1:54pm on 26 Oct 2016 Sticking with pokies, Ainsworth shares have dived more than 20 per cent after the company's poker machine sales have slumped by almost 30 per cent, and the company warned its half year pre-tax profit will more than halve. Ainsworth said competition in Australia and a reduced level of purchasing by gaming operators and casinos had resulted in sales since July 1 dropping about 30 per cent compared to a year ago. "The trends affecting the company's sales in domestic markets in the second half of 2016 have continued into the new financial year," the company said. Pre-tax profit in the six months to December 31, excluding foreign exchange movements, is expected to be about $15 million, down from $35 million in the prior corresponding period. Ainsworth said its half year financial results would also reflect greater spending in research and development to build a pipeline of new products to boost future performance. Shares are down 11 per cent at $1.80, after earlier dropping to $1.60, the lowest in more than four years. 1:39pm on 26 Oct 2016 Casino operator Crown Resorts and slot machine maker Aristocrat Leisure are being sued, over claims a pokie machine provided misleading information to customers about their chances of winning. The lawsuit, filed in the Federal Court, "will focus on the design of machines contributing to players being deliberately deceived on their prospects of winning," Maurice Blackburn said in a statement. The case is being brought by Shonica Guy, who allegedly suffered significant losses over 14 years of playing on pokies. Guy is not seeking damages but court-ordered declarations that the companies engaged in misleading conduct and an injunction banning them from continuing to provide the machine in its current configuration, the court filing said. The lawsuit comes at a time when Crown is grappling with a crisis in China after 18 company employees were detained for suspected "gambling crimes". The filing said a slot machine called Dolphin Treasure at Crown's flagship casino in Melbourne suggested its five "reels" had the same number of characters but one column had substantially more, lowering the chances a gambler would win. "If successful, the litigation will have ramifications for the design of all poker machines in the industry," Maurice Blackburn said. Crown said in a statement it will "vigorously defend any claim." While Aristocrat didn't immediately respond to a request for comment, the company said in a statement last month it "emphatically rejects any suggestion that its games are designed to encourage problem gambling." Shares in Crown and Aristocrat are both down more than 2 per cent, with shares in the former hitting a one-year low. Misleading design? Photo: Erin Jonasson 1:28pm on 26 Oct 2016 Sharemarkets around the region are in the red after Apple's earnings disappointed and as oil prices slip further - but the ASX is the clear underperformer. Japan's Nikkei is down 0.15 per cent, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong has lost 0.6 per cent, the Shanghai Composite is off 0.2 per cent and Korea's Kospi has fallen 1.3 per cent.  "Apple's forward expectations aren't great and it's susceptible to more of a pullback," said James Audiss, senior wealth manager at Shaw and Partners. "Now plenty of countries want an exemption to the OPEC output cuts and that's putting pressure on oil." Brent oil is down another 1 per cent to $US50.27, pulled down by a report of surging US crude inventories, rising output in Nigeria and squabbling among producers about a planned output cut, which together re-ignited concerns over a global supply glut. 1:14pm on 26 Oct 2016 Photo: World Bank New Zealand has overtaken Singapore as the best country in the the world to do business, according to the World Bank. Singapore slipped to second in the bank's 2017 "Doing Business" report after topping the ranking for a decade. Finland dropped out of the top 10, falling to 13th. Macedonia, which placed 92nd a decade ago, improved two spots from a year earlier to No. 10. The report ranks countries based on 11 sets of indicators such as the ease of starting a business, dealing with construction permits, accessing electricity and obtaining credit. For the first time, the Washington-based development lender took gender factors into consideration in assessing how easy it is to start a business, register property and enforce contracts. New Zealand, which has one of the fastest-growing economies in the developed world, leads the rankings with the fewest number of procedures to start a business and the shortest time to fulfil them, along with strong legal rights, the bank said. Brunei Darussalam, Kazakhstan, Kenya, Belarus and Indonesia made the biggest strides in business-friendly reforms. The US dropped to eighth spot from seventh, while Japan retained its 34th place and China rose to 78th from 84th. India's ranking was unchanged at 130th. The methods used to create the rankings have faced criticism. An independent panel appointed by World Bank President Jim Yong Kim found it used a narrow source of information and had the potential to be misinterpreted, according to a 2013 report. The rankings shouldn't be used to apply a one-size-fits-all template for development, the panel found. 12:50pm on 26 Oct 2016 Time for a midday wrap, and it's a sea of red on the bourse, led by a hefty 5 per cent drop in heavyweight Wesfarmers following its underwhelming sales update. The ASX 200 index is off 82 points or 1.5 per cent to 5361, hitting a month low. The Aussie dollar has pulled back a little from this morning's post-CPI jump, but is still 0.4 US cents higher for the day and last fetched 76.9 US cents. Winners are few and far between, with only 10 of the top 200 in the green, so the selling looks indiscriminate for the most part. The aforementioned tumble in Wesfarmers shares is the biggest drag, while Woolies is down a much more moderate 0.2 per cent and on a day like this that looks like a win. Among the winners are iron ore  and coal miners, which are still enjoying support from a climbing commodity price. Rio is up 1 per cent and Fortescue is ahead 1.4 per cent. Whitehaven Coal is up 1.9 per cent. Gold miners are ahead as well, but energy stocks are well off, down 2.7 per cent as a group as the oil price continues to fall: brent crude is off 1 per cent today at $US50.28/barrel. That has presumably contributed to the 0.9 per cent drop in BHP. The big banks are off by between 1.1 per cent and 1.4 per cent, ahead of NAB's profit result tomorrow that kicks of the bank reporting season. NAB spin-off CYBG is down 5 per cent on reports the British bank had made a bid to buy a consumer lending unit owned by RBS. And investors have continued to dump Bega Cheese after yesterday's trading update, pushing it down another 4.6 per cent, while Ardent Leisure has tumbled a further 12 per cent following yesterday afternoon's tragic accident at Dreamworld. Both stocks are now off 20 per cent in the two sessions. Winners and losers at lunch. Photo: Bloomberg Back to top 12:07pm on 26 Oct 2016 A few reactions on Twitter to the inflation numbers. Overall sense is they're nothing to get too excited about but strong enough for punters not to have to worry about what the RBA could be up to next Tuesday: Size of AUD bounce on CPI suggests market caught a bit short. Maybe now free to follow commodities higher? RBA rate cut <10% chance by Dec— Sean Callow (@seandcallow) October 26, 2016 Market seem to be ignoring core measures today.— Jacob Greber (@jacobgreber) October 26, 2016 RBA date OIS pricing being removed sharply post CPI, breakevens up, AUD firmer. Market asking if the 'Lowe' is in for CPI.. @katie_hill2— Martin Whetton (@martin_whetton) October 26, 2016 Economists, traders, market enthusiasts etc free to enjoy Melb Cup Day #NoRateCut— Brooke Corte (@brookecorte) October 26, 2016 CPI data pumps the Aussie Dollar up, but is a curb on further cuts enough to drive $AUDUSD through wedge resistance? pic.twitter.com/MuLlrWdwpH— John Kicklighter (@JohnKicklighter) October 26, 2016 The herd. Looking forward to all the PHD's living on upper levels commenting on Aussie inflation over the next 48 hours.— Peter Morgan (@psimpsonmorgan) October 26, 2016 RBA only looks at core measures.— Justin Fabo (@justinfabo) October 26, 2016 11:51am on 26 Oct 2016 The reason for the jump in the dollar back above US77¢ is that market pricing is now pretty much ruling out another RBA cut this year following the stronger than expected headline (and largely in line core) inflation numbers. Bets on a Melbourne Cup rate cut next Tuesday have dropped to just 4 per cent, from 16 per cent this morning, while chances of further easing in the first half of next year have fallen to just over 30 per cent, from 44 per cent, according to Citi. The inflation data has culled any chance of another rate cut this year, says ThinkMarkets senior market analyst Matt Simpson. "The RBA will see today's pick-up in quarterly inflation as a net positive from record low rates of 1.5 per cent, so this pushes any concerns of further easing well back into 2017." 11:35am on 26 Oct 2016 The inflation data is in, and it's a little stronger than economists had been expecting, and the Aussie dollar is climbing as a result. Headline CPI grew by 0.7 per cent over the quarter, against 0.4 per cent over the June period, bringing the annual rate to 1.3 per cent from 1 per cent. Core inflation has weakened ever-so-slightly over the September, with the trimmed mean CPI rising 0.4 per cent against the prior 0.5 per cent, leaving the annual rate unchanged at 1.7 per cent. The weighted median on a quarterly basis has similarly eased to 0.3 per cent from 0.4 per cent, ad the annual rate is steady at 1.3 per cent. The Aussie has climbed half a penny to US77 cents, the day's high. 11:24am on 26 Oct 2016 Jim Rogers, one-time hedge fund partner of George Soros, expects Donald Trump could still win the US election tipping global markets into turmoil and sending investors into agriculture and US dollars for safety. Speaking at a private event in Sydney, Rogers, who founded the Quantum Fund in the '70s with Soros, said he would not buy any bonds anywhere in the world and that he was concerned about global debt levels – even in Australia where he said politicians were not doing enough. "I suspect [the winner] will be Trump but whoever it will be it's not going to be good," Rogers said. "I hope you are all prepared because there is going to be some very serious problems in the world. Trade wars always lead to bankruptcies. "I still own a lot of US dollars because there is a lot of turmoil coming, but then I think even the dollar will get overpriced and possibly turn into a bubble." Rogers, who has held a bearish outlook for some time and whose investment performance is largely private, suggested a number of issues including the separatist political movements in Europe, struggling pension funds in the US, the failure of quantitative easing and high debt levels would all snowball into serious market turmoil. He could not be specific about timing but said the shorters always seemed to get squeezed before the market tanked. Here's more at afr.com ($) Jim Rogers says that investors should be prepared for turmoil in global markets.  Photo: Ben Rushton 11:13am on 26 Oct 2016 So where's the inflation red line for the RBA, below which it might be prompted to cut rates again? Most analysts reckon that if core inflation were to fall below 0.3 per cent over the quarter, or 1.25 per cent annually, the central bank will strongly lean towards more easing. TD Securities chief macro strategist Annette Beacher has put together four scenarios and their likely impact on the market. 1. 'NEUTRAL' (35% probability): a "consensus" quarterly core CPI increase of +0.4%/qtr and 1.55%/yr is 'as expected' cements the case for another cash rate pause at 1.5% at next Tuesday's RBA Board meeting. 'As expected', however, could still briefly lift the AUD and short bond yields as the risk of a cut next week shrinks even further to near-zero.  2. Slightly DOVISH (55%): A quarterly core CPI print closer to our +0.3%/qtr forecast may be "below consensus" but with the annual rate still printing at 1.5%/yr, does not provide a trigger for the RBA to cut next week.  However, a 'below market' print could see (market pricing) increase the risk of another cut (currently barely 50/50 by mid-2017) and puts modest downward pressure on the AUD, towards $US0.76. 3. Very DOVISH (5%): A flat or slightly negative core print provides the biggest headache for the markets and the RBA. It was the significant 0.5 percentage point downside miss earlier this year that prompted the "shock" May RBA cut, and a similar downside miss will test the RBA under Lowe. Will the Bank cut again next week on such a significant downside miss or is 1 per cent (core inflation) within Dr Lowe's tolerance? We can see markets pricing the risk of a November 1 cut jumping well past 50 per cent on this outcome, and trading closer to 100 per cent for the February 2017 RBA board meeting. Short bond yields in this case can easily retest sub-cash levels while the AUD could plunge to $US0.74 (risking the May lows of $US0.72). 4. HAWKISH (5%): An average quarterly print of +0.6 per cent/qtr or higher means a minimum 1.75 per cent over the year, and hence offers modest upside compared with the RBA projection of 1.5 per cent/yr. This hawkish outcome not only cements the case for pausing next week, the OIS curve could steepen dramatically. Why? When the RBA eventually hints at a diluted easing bias, the markets tend to swiftly shift to pricing "the next move is up" for the cash rate.  On this scenario, 3yr bond yields jump past 1.80% towards 1.90%, and the AUD could easily retest April's $US0.78 cyclical high.
